content: The Act titled "Health Insurance Affordability and Equity Act of 1999" introduces a new section, SEC. 25B, which provides a credit for health insurance costs for previously uninsured individuals and those with COBRA coverage. The Health Insurance Affordability and Equity Act of 1999 introduces a new section, SEC. 25B, which allows a tax credit for health insurance costs for individuals with qualified coverage. The credit is equal to 60% of the amount paid for coverage for the taxpayer, spouse, and dependents. There are monthly limitations based on the type of coverage, with a maximum credit amount for eligible months. The Health Insurance Affordability and Equity Act of 1999 introduces a new section, SEC. 25B, which allows a tax credit for health insurance costs for individuals with qualified coverage. The credit is equal to 60% of the amount paid for coverage for the taxpayer, spouse, and dependents. There are monthly limitations based on the type of coverage, with a maximum credit amount for eligible months. Eligible months are defined as those that begin at least 1 year after the individual was eligible for group health insurance or participated in a group health plan with qualified insurance. Joint returns require both spouses to have eligible months. Amounts paid for coverage of an individual for any month are not considered under subsection (a) if coverage was in place at the start of the month. The limitation on the tax credit for health insurance costs does not apply to individuals covered under specific medical care programs or certain military, veteran, or government employee programs. There is a special rule for married individuals who file separately but do not live apart from their spouse. Additionally, there is a limitation based on adjusted gross income. The limitation on the tax credit for health insurance costs does not apply to certain individuals. A reduction in the credit amount is based on adjusted gross income, with specific calculations outlined in paragraphs (1) and (2). The tax credit for health insurance costs is limited based on adjusted gross income. The modified adjusted gross income includes certain exclusions. The applicable dollar amount varies based on the number of individuals covered and marital status. Rounding rules apply for amounts not multiples of $10. For tax purposes, marital status is determined under section 7703. Qualified health insurance, defined as medical care under section 213(d), excludes coverage from group health plans and certain other contracts. The text discusses the treatment of continuation coverage under a group health plan for individuals with COBRA coverage. It states that such coverage is considered qualified health insurance and eligible months include months of COBRA coverage. Special rules include coordination with other deductions, denial of credit to dependents, and an inflation adjustment. The text discusses the inflation adjustment for dollar amounts in subsection (c)(3) for taxable years beginning after 2000. Amounts are increased based on the cost-of-living adjustment for the calendar year. Rounding rules apply if the adjusted amount is not a multiple of $100. The text introduces a deduction for qualified health insurance costs of employees and self-employed individuals, effective for taxable years starting after December 31, 1999. It amends the Internal Revenue Code to include a new section on costs of qualified health insurance.
